Cohen-Moore-Neisendorfer and Ravenel's spectra

Apr 18, 2019

It’s been a long time. In the previous post, we asked whether the “-quotient” of “by ” is “”. Lots of scare quotes there. I gave a sketch of the story one might want to run, but I’d like to be more precise in this post.

Last time, we constructed a fiber sequence

where the first map detects . This comes by looping the Cohen-Moore-Neisendorfer-Anick fibration. The map Thomifies to , and the induced bundle over Thomifies to . We therefore get a map which Thomifies to . The element detected by lives in degree . One needs to check that this element is not divisible by ; if it was, then since the composite is multiplication by , the element is divisible by if and only if factors through the Cohen-Moore-Neisendorfer map . Since there is a fiber sequence

this would imply that the map is null, i.e., that you have a map , which necessarily splits the orientation . That’s absurd (check on homology).

This result already seems to be new, and raises numerous interesting questions. For instance, consider the operadic filtration of . Upon Thomifying, the above result gives rise to a -module filtration of . How does this filtration relate to the Brown-Gitler filtration of ? I expect that the answer comes from understanding as a fiber sequence of filtered -spaces.

Let’s move on to the general case. We know, by the discussion in the previous post, that there is a fiber sequence

where is called an Anick space, and the connecting map gives the degree map on upon composition with the double suspension. Let denote the integer such that . What we’re now reduced to is constructing a map whose Thom spectrum is an -ring, and admits an -map to . Once we have this -map , the usual Dyer-Lashof hopping argument will allow us to conclude that this map is an equivalence.

There are a few immediate obstructions: first, I don’t know if is an -ring; second, I don’t know if is an -space. How, then, do we obtain an -ring structure on ? I’ll come back to this in a bit; let’s first try to construct a map . A conjecture of Gray’s says that splits off for all and all . Since splits off of in an -manner, it suffices to construct a map .

We run into a structural issue (again!): since , we’d be done if was an -ring, and we could construct a map . But is not an -ring! Nonetheless, we can construct a map

Indeed, consider the element ; by our choice of , this element is -torsion, so we can extend the map to a map from . The collection of such extensions is a torsor over — and this group is huge! Indecomposables living in this degree, are precisely choices of the element . Choose a bijection between the collection of such extensions and , and make a choice of (perhaps we can do something canonical here, but let’s return back to this later); then, we get a map , as desired.

As I said before, the failure of to be an -ring implies that we can’t necessarily extend this map to . However, there’s a potential fix. There’s a universal -ring with an -map to ; this is the -topological Hochschild cohomology of . The main theorem (on page 3) of this paper shows that this -ring is , where the action of on comes by the conjugation action (using the group structure) of on . So: if our element is central, i.e., is in the image of the canonical map , and it is still -torsion in there, then we get a map

note that the collection of such maps are in noncanonical bijection with ; and this map extends to . Let’s talk about whether this is true below. OK, so we have a map

This gives us the desired map . The map is , so the Thom spectrum is an -ring. Moreover, splits off by -maps.

Let’s now return to the question of whether the Thom spectrum is an -ring. I’d like to conjecture that in fact admits the structure of an -ring, and that splits off by -maps.

What about constructing the -map ? Suppose that the composite is an -map. Then we have an -map

By the -ness of this map, it’s determined by what happens on the bottom copy of . The map from the bottom cell of this object to is null, because has no odd-dimensional homotopy. There’s therefore an extension of the map from to a map from the top cell, which is . The resulting map detects an element in — and the choice of such an extension corresponds exactly to the choice of an element that we made earlier when constructing the map . Having already chosen this to be an indecomposable, we find that the composite

is null, because all indecomposables in degree die in . By general Thom spectra machinery, we get an -map , and I expect this to be an -map. If we have all of this, then we’re done.

That’s a lot of stuff, so let’s summarize what we’ve assumed:

  1. The element should be central, i.e., come from ; moreover, it’s -torsion in .
  2. in fact admits the structure of an -ring, and that is an -ring which splits off by -maps.
  3. The composite is an -map.
  4. We chose a bijection between the collection of extensions of to and , and made a choice of .

Let me make some remarks. There’s a clever way of phrasing (4) in such a way that the two times it’s used above cancel each other out. All we need to show is that there is a choice of extension (dotted arrow) in the below diagram such that there is a choice of indecomposable element for which the following diagram commutes:

The left vertical map should be dotted, but I don’t know how to do that in AMScd.

As for (2): I think that showing that admits the structure of an -ring shouldn’t be too hard (and is in fact probably obvious?), but showing that is an -ring which splits off by -maps should be of equivalent difficulty to proving that is an -ring. Perhaps being in fact implies (2).

The “most approachable” part of this is (1). It seems apt to remark that Jeremy Hahn and Mike Hopkins had thought about proving a result like “” before, but their approach was to try to prove that was central in . This seemed to be really hard: the element is a purely algebraic thing (it’s also not well-defined; but I guess we made a choice, too), and so it’s quite hard to show that it comes from , where the action is defined geometrically.

Here’s a small piece of evidence for (1): let be a -local -ring for odd , and let be an element in odd degree. The map extends to an -map . A result of Serre’s says that there is an equivalence , induced by the suspension on and the Whitehead product . Therefore, there is an -equivalence . We conclude that there is an -map , i.e., an -map . Nothing about this discussion is special to the element , though; I think that constructing the extension of the map constructed above to will be the challenging part of this program.

Note that the composite

then factors through , and hence is null (since the composite is an -map and is therefore determined by its effect on the bottom cell). In particular, item (3) is unnecessary (recall that the only reason for wanting (3) is since we needed the giant composite above to be null). So, really, we only need items (1) and (2).

(Added later: in fact, item (2) can be made even weaker: the Dyer-Lashof hopping argument only needs to exist, for which you don’t need the entire -structure — it already exists in the homology of a homotopy commutative ring!)
